File.Title: Proportion of Glutamate- and Aspartate-Immunoreactive Neurons in the Efferent Pathways of the Rat Visual Cortex Varies According to the Target
File.Authors: I. DORI, A. DINOPOULOS, M.E. CAVANAGH, AND J.G. PARNAVELAS

Abstract.S: Immunohistochemistry, with antisera directed against glutamate (Glu) or aspartate (Asp), was combined with wheat germ agglutinin-horseradish peroxidase (WGA-HRP) histochemistry to examine the distribution, morphology, and proportions of Gluand Asp-containing neurons that give rise to corticofugal and callosal projections of the rat visual cortex.
WGA-HRP injections in the dorsal lateral geniculate nucleus resulted in retrograde labelling of small and medium-sized cells throughout layer VI of the visual cortex.
Of these cells, 60% were also Glu-immunoreactive and 6 1% Asp-positive.
WGA-HRP injections in the superior colliculus labelled large and medium-sized neurons in the upper portion of layer V of the visual cortex.
Of these cells, 46% were also stained for Glu and 66% for Asp.
Injections in the pontine nuclei resulted in retrograde labelling of cells in the deeper part of cortical layer V.
Retrogradely labelled cells, which were also immunoreactive for Glu or Asp, were large pyramidal cells.
Corticopontine neurons, which were also Glu-positive, accounted for 42% of the total number of WGA-HRP labelled cells, whilst for Asp-positive neurons this percentage was 51%.
Finally, after injections in the visual cortex, retrogradely labelled small and medium-sized cells were found throughout layers 11-VI in the contralateral visual cortex.
Of these neurons, 38% were also labelled for Glu while 49% were also Asp-immunoreactive.

The present results demonstrate that substantial proportions of projection neurons in the rat visual cortex are immunoreactive for Glu or Asp, suggesting that these excitatory amino acids are the major transmitters used by the cortical efferent systems examined.
Furthermore, the proportions of these immunoreactive neurons in the efferent pathways vary according to the target. e 1992 Wiley-Liss, Inc.

Introduction.S: Extensive investigations during the past 30 years have shown that the amino acids L-glutamate (Glu) and L-aspartate (Asp) have excitatory actions on many neurons in the central nervous system.
The excitatory effects of these amino acids on cerebral cortical neurons were first demonstrated by Krnjevic and Phillis ('63) and later confirmed by others (Hess and Murata, '74).

Since then, a plethora of neurochemical, pharmacological, physiological, and morphological studies have provided a substantial body of evidence suggesting that these amino acids may be involved in cortical transmission (see Fagg and Foster, '83; Ottersen and Storm-Mathisen, '84a; Streit, '84, for reviews).

Until recently, the direct demonstration of neurons likely to use these substances as neurotransmitters has proved very difficult as Glu and Asp, being key metabolites in the brain, are present in all cells.
Thus, earlier investigations have used indirect approaches to demonstrate that Glu and Asp are present within cortical projection neurons or in cortical efferent pathways.

Lesions of various cortical efferent systems including the corticopontine, corticocollicular, corticothalamic, and corticostriatal pathways, resulted in decreases in the endogenous level, release, and high-affinity uptake of Glu and Asp in the respective subcortical targets.

Injections of the tritiated D-forms of Glu and Asp in subcortical and callosal termination sites of cortical projections resulted in retrograde labelling of pyramidal neurons (see Fagg and Foster, '83; Streit, '84, for reviews).

Furthermore, iontophoretic application of specific amino acid antagonists at termination sites of various corticofugal fibers blocked excitation in the postsynaptic neurons (Spencer, '76; Stone, '76, '79).

The direct demonstration of cortical neurons that may use excitatory amino acids as neurotransmitters has been achieved as a result of the production of antibodies directed against these amino acids conjugated to protein carriers that specifically demonstrate Glu and Asp in perfusionfixed tissue (Storm-Mathisen et al., '83; Campistron et al., '86; Mad1 et al., '86, '87; Hepler et al., '88).

Using these antibodies, investigators have provided descriptions of the morphology and distribution of amino acid-containing neurons in the neocortex of a number of mammalian species (Ottersen and Storm-Mathisen, '84b; Conti et al., '87b, '89).

In a recent immunocytochemical study at the light and electron microscopic level, we reported that in the visual cortex of the rat Gluand Asp-immunoreactivity was found in pyramidal cells, which are regarded as the projection neurons of the cortex, distributed throughout layers 11-VI.
The Glu-immunoreactive cells were exclusively pyramidal, but of those positive for Asp 10% were nonpyramidal (Dori et al., '89).

Methods.S: MATERIALS AND METHODS
Twenty-five adult pigmented and Sprague Dawley albino rats, weighing 250-300 g each, were used in this study.
peroxidase-antiperoxidase
Surgery and WGA-HRP injections
The animals were deeply anaesthetized with Sagatal(25 mg/kg) prior to being mounted on a stereotaxic apparatus.
The skull was opened and the dura removed under a surgical microscope.
WGA-HRP (Sigma; 4% in sterile saline) was injected under pressure by means of a 1 ~1 Hamilton microsyringe.
The needle was slowly directed to the appropriate injection site, whose stereotaxic coordinates were determined with reference to the atlas of the rat brain by Paxinos and Watson ('86).
For injections into the dorsal lateral geniculate nucleus (dLGN), a glass micropipette glued to the Hamilton microsyringe was used in order to achieve a restricted delivery of the tracer.
Seven rats each received 0.02 pl of the WGA-HRP solution in the dLGN.
The micropipette tip was directed to the target through the contralateral hemisphere.
Another three animals each received 0.10 pl WGA-HRP in the superior colliculus (SC).
In these animals, the needle-tip was directed to the target through the contralateral hemisphere in order to avoid the ipsilateral cortex.
A group of five rats each received a total of 0.25 p1 WGA-HRP solution in four separate sites in the pontine nuclei.
In these injections the needle was angled towards the brain stem via the cerebellum.
Finally, in each of 10 rats, a total of 0.50 p1 of the tracer was injected unilaterally in four sites at the borders of cortical area 17 with areas 18 and 18a.
In all animals, WGA-HRP was delivered over a period of 10-15 minutes, and the needle remained in place for 10 minutes following completion of each injection.
Perfusion and tissue preparation

The animals were allowed to survive for 48 hours, after which they were deeply reanaesthetized with ether and perfused through the ascending aorta with 200 ml of fixative solution containing 4% paraformaldehyde and 0.2% glutaraldehyde in 0.1 M phosphate buffer, pH 7.4 (PB), followed by 300 ml of the same fixative without glutaraldehyde.

This schedule was selected after preliminary experiments to determine the optimal fixation conditions for staining of Gluand Asp-containing neurons and is very similar to that recommended by Hepler et al. ('881, who raised and characterized the antisera used in the present study.
The brains were immediately removed from the skulls, postfixed in 4% paraformaldehyde in PB for 1 hour, and then transferred into PB or 30% sucrose in PB for approximately 18 hours at 4Â°C.
Serial sections were cut from the occipital cortex at 40 km in the coronal plane, with either a Vibratome or a freezing microtome.
Sections through the visual cortex were collected in PB in groups of three.

The first and second sections of each group were first processed for WGA-HRP-histochemistry and subsequently every first section was processed for Glu and every second one for Asp immunohistochemistry.
The third section of each group was stained with toluidine blue.
Control sections were kept for WGA-HRP histochemistry or immunohistochemistry alone.
Sections through each of the injection sites were cut and processed for WGA-HRP histochemistry .
WGA-HRP histochemistry and amino acid immunohistochemistry
Free-floating sections were processed according to the protocol of Horn and Hoffman ('87).

The sections were rinsed six times in ice-cold distilled water and then preincubated in a mixture of two solutions containing 100 mg sodium nitroferricyanide, 92.5 ml distilled water, and 5 ml of 0.2 M citrate buffer, pH 3.3 (solution A), and 5 mg tetramethyl benzidine (TMB) dissolved in 2.5 ml absolute alcohol (solution B) for 20 minutes.
They were then incubated for 40 minutes in a fresh solution of 100 ml preincubation medium to which 200 mg P-D-glucose, 0.5 mg glucose oxidase, and 40 mg ammonium chloride were added.
Sections were subsequently incubated in an icecooled stabilization medium of 5% ammonium heptamolybdate in distilled water for 20 minutes.

They were then rinsed in PB for 30 seconds and incubated for 8 minutes in a solution of 33'-diaminobenzidine tetrahydrochloride (DAB; Sigma; 0.05% in PB) to which 2.5 m1/100 ml of 1% cobalt acetate was added dropwise, followed by the addition of 1% H,O, to give a final concentration of 0.01%.
Sections were finally rinsed five times in cold 0.1 M phosphate buffered saline, pH 7.4 (PBS).

After completion of the WGA-HRP-histochemical procedure, the sections were incubated in a 10% methanol/3% H,O, solution for 20 minutes to destroy the residual activity of HRP and endogenous peroxidase.

Sections processed for WGA-HRP histochemistry alone were rinsed in PB, mounted on gelatinized slides, air-dried, dehydrated through an ascending series of alcohols, and, finally, coverslipped with DPX.
Sections used for combined WGA-HRP histochemistryimmunohistochemistry were rinsed in PBS and subsequently incubated in normal goat serum (NGS; 2% in PBS) for 15 minutes.

They were then transferred into primary antiserum to Glu or Asp (used at a dilution of 1:3,000 in PBS with 2% NGS) and incubated for 1 hour at room temperature, followed by 36-40 hours at 4"C, and returned to room temperature for an additional 1 hour.
These sections were subsequently rinsed in PBS, incubated again in NGS for 15 minutes, and then processed with the peroxidase-antiperoxidase (PAP) immunohistochemical technique.
Sections were incubated in sheep anti-rabbit IgG (150) in PBS with 2% NGS for 45 minutes, washed in PBS, and transferred into rabbit PAP (1:80) in PBS with 2% NGS for 30 minutes.
The incubations in IgG and PAP were subsequently repeated.
Following the second incubation in PAP, the sections were washed in Tris-buffered saline, pH 7.4 (TBS), and placed in a solution of DAB (0.04% in Tris/HCl buffer) for 10 minutes.
They were then transferred to a fresh solution of DAB containing 0.01% H,O, for 10 minutes and finally rinsed in 0.1 M Tris/HCl buffer and then in PB.
After completion of the immunohistochemical procedure, sections were mounted on gelatinized slides, air-dried, dehydrated, and coverslipped with DPX.
The antisera to the amino acids used in the present study were raised in rabbits against Glu or Asp conjugated to keyhole limpet hemocyanin with glutaraldehyde.
Detailed methods of the preparation and characterization of both antisera by immunoabsorption and immunohistochemistry have been published earlier (Hepler et al., '88).
In addition, details of the method and antisera specificity in the neocortex have been reported previously (Conti et al., '87b, '89; Dori et al., '89).
Data analysis
Sections were examined with a Zeiss light microscope.
For every section examined, the cytoarchitectonic borders of area 17 and the extent of the cortical layers were determined from adjacent Nissl-stained sections.

Counts of cells in this visual cortical area were made, with a x25 objective, in two animals from every group of rats injected with WGA-HRP, and the percentages of double (WGA-HRPlabelled and immunoreactive)versus single (WGA-HRPstained)-labelled cells were calculated.
In order to show the overall distribution of each group of cells, Gluor Aspimmunoreactive, WGA-HRP-labelled, and double-labelled cells were plotted with a drawing tube attached to the microscope.
Profiles of both singleand double-labelled cells were drawn with a camera lucida at x40, and crosssectional areas of cell somata were measured with a digitizing tablet linked to a microcomputer.
In order to avoid underestimating cell size, only profiles that showed a nucleus and/or apical dendrite were measured.

Results.S: Consistent with our earlier light and electron microscopic investigation in the visual cortex of the rat ( Dori et al . , ' 89 ) , the present observations suggest that both Gluand Aspimmunoreactive neurons were pyramidal cells distributed in layers 11 - VI of area 17, with an increased concentration in layers I1 and 111.
Aspartate - labelled neurons differed from Glu - labelled in that a few were nonpyramidal and they were additionally found in layer I in very small numbers .

In sections processed for both WGA - HRP histochemistry and amino acid immunohistochemistry , three types of labelling in cells were readily identified : 1 ) Cells that were Gluor Asp - immunoreactive displayed an intense fine granular brown reaction product evenly distributed throughout the perikarya and proximal dendrites . 2 ) Neurons that had effectively transported WGA - HRP displayed a black coarse granular reaction product in their somata and proximal dendrites . 3 ) Neurons that were Gluor Aspimmunoreactive and WGA - HRP - positive ( double labelled ) demonstrated an easily distinguished combination of both brown reaction product and black WGA - HRP granules in their somata and proximal dendrites .

The patterns of distribution of WGA - HRP - positive cells in the visual cortex corresponded to those described in previous tracing studies in rats in which subcortical and cortical target areas were injected with HRP ( Sefton et al . , ' 81 ; Wiesendanger and Wiesendanger , ' 82 ; Miller and Vogt , ' 84 ; Olavarria and Van Sluyters , ' 85 ; Hallman et al . , ' 88 ; Legg et al . , ' 89 ) .

Counts of WGA - HRP - labelled cells in 500 pm strips of sections through the visual cortex processed for WGA - HRP histochemistry alone , as well as in adjacent sections processed for both WGA - HRP histochemistry and immunohistochemistry , revealed comparable numbers of retrogradely labelled cells .
This control suggested that the immunohistochemical procedure did not result in the masking or loss of the WGA - HRP reaction product .

In addition , comparison of the distributions and staining intensity of Gluor Asp - immunoreactive cells between sections processed for both WGA - HRP histochemistiy and immunohistochemistry , and adjacent sections processed for immunohistochemistry alone , showed similar frequencies as well as staining intensities of immunoreactive neurons .
This suggested that the immunohistochemical reaction product was unaffected by the preceding histochemical procedure.

TTE.S: WGA - HRP injections in the dorsal lateral geniculate nucleus .

These injections resulted in either restricted labelling within the boundaries of the nucleus ( Fig . lB ) , or in labelling of the dLGN and the ventral lateral geniculate nucleus ( vLGN ) as well ( Fig . 1A ) .

Analysis was restricted to layer VI , since it has been established that cortical afferents to the dLGN arise exclusively in this layer of the rat visual cortex ( Sefton et al . , 31 ) , whereas afferents to the vLGN arise from layer V ( Cosenza and Moore , ' 84 ) .
WGA - HRP granules were localized in neurons throughout layer VI of the ipsilateral visual areas 17 ( Figs . 4D , 5D ) and 18.

WGA-HRP-positive neurons, which were also immunoreactive for Asp (Fig. 1C) or Glu (Fig. lD), were restricted to small and medium-sized pyramids, but the Asp-immunoreactive neurons projecting to the dLGN were smaller on average (Table I).
In a sample of 797 WGA - HRP - stained cells in layer VI , from two rats with injections that spread in both the dLGN and vLGN , 60% were also Glu - immunoreactive ( Table 2 ) .
In a separate sample of 762 corticothalamic neurons from the same animals, 61% contained Asp (Table 3).
When counts were made in two animals with WGA - HRP injections restricted to the dLGN , the double - labelled neurons were 60% and 62% , respectively .
WGA - HRP injections in the superior colliculus .
WGAHRP injections in the SC resulted in intense labelling of its superficial layers ( Fig . 2A ) .

Retrogradely labelled cells were located primarily in the upper half of layer V of area 17 ( Figs . 4C , 5C ) as well as the borders of area 17 with areas 18 and 18a ipsilateral to the injected hemisphere .
WGA-HRPstained neurons that were also immunoreactive for Glu (Fig. 2B,C) or Asp were medium or large pyramids (Table 1).
The Asp neurons projecting to the SC were on average larger than the Glu neurons , but the large Meynert cells which were Asp - immunoreactive ( Dori et al . , ' 89 ) were not retrogradely labelled .
In sections processed for both WGA - HRP histochemistry and immunohistochemistry for Glu , a total of 634 retrogradely labelled neurons from two animals were counted .
Of these, 46% were also Glu-immunoreactive (Table 2).
In double - labelled sections stained with the antiserum to Asp , 544 neurons that project to the SC were counted , 66% of which were also Asp - positive ( Table 3 ) .
WGA - HRP injections in the pontine nuclei .

WGA - HRP injections in the pons ( P ) resulted in complete and intense labelling throughout the rostrocaudal extent of the pontine nuclei , with minor diffusion into the neighbouring reticular formation or into the contralateral side ( Fig . 3A ) .
The WGA - HRP was retrogradely transported into cell bodies in area 17, ipsilateral to the injection .
Perikarya filled with WGA - HRP were located in layer V , almost exclusively in its deeper portion ( Vb ) ( Figs . 4B , 5B ) .

Retrogradely labelled cells that were also immunoreactive for Glu or Asp included the largest cortical neurons that were stained with either of the two antisera , although these were very few in number ( Table 1 ) .
The Asp-labelled corticopontine cell population included the large Meynert cells (Fig. 3B,C) as well as small to medium-sized neurons located at the border between layers Va and Vb.
The presence of these small cells reduced the mean size below that of Glu-immunoreactive neurons (Table 1).
The Glu - immunoreactive projection cells were almost exclusively the largest neurons labelled with the Glu antiserum ( Fig . 3D ) .
In sections processed for WGA - HRP histochemistry and immunohistochemistry for Glu , a total of 513 retrogradely labelled neurons was counted .
Of these cells, 216 (42%) were also Glu-immunoreactive (Table 2), a proportion very similar to that reported in an earlier study of Glucontaining cortical projection neurons (Dinopoulos et al., '89).
In sections processed for visualization of both WGAHRP and Asp - immunoreactivity , a total of 667 neurons labelled with the retrograde tracer was counted .
WGA - HRP injections in the visual cortex .
After WGAHRP injections in the visual cortex , staining was observed throughout area 17 but more intensely at the border regions between area 17 and areas 18 and 18a .

Retrogradely labelled cells were observed predominantly in two " columns " around the boundaries of area 17 and areas 18 and 18a of the contralateral hemisphere , but a substantial number was also found throughout area 17.
WGA - HRP - positive neurons were distributed throughout layers 11 - VI ( Figs . 4A , 5A ) .
Analysis restricted to the border of area 17 with 18a showed that cells with callosal connections that were also Gluor Asp - immunoreactive were small or mediumsized pyramidal neurons ( Table 1 ) .
Large cells in layer V , which were immunoreactive for Glu or Asp , were not retrogradely labelled .
In a sample of 1,165 retrogradely labelled neurons that were counted through layers 11 - VI , 447 ( 38% ) were also Glu - positive ( Table 2 ) .
However, this percentage increased to 50% when counts were restricted to layers 11-111.
In a sample of 952 WGA - HRP - positive neurons through layers 11 - VI , 466 ( 49% ) were also Asp - immunoreactive ( Table 3 ) .

Results.S: This percentage increased to 51% when layers 11-111 were considered alone.

Discussion.S: DISCUSSION

The antisera to Glu and Asp used in the present investigation have been characterized by immunoblots and immunoabsorption tests on sections of various parts of the nervous system including the cerebral cortex.

A number of recently published reports have provided strong evidence that the antisera used here stain the neurotransmitter rather than the metabolic pool of individual neurons: 1) All Gluand the vast majority of Asp-immunoreactive neurons in the rat visual cortex were identified at the light and electron microscopic level as pyramidal cells, which reflects remarkable selectivity of the antisera (Dori et al., '89).

This selectivity may be a consequence of the higher rate of synthesis of the neurotransmitter pool of Glu or Asp when compared to the metabolic pool (Storm-Mathisen and Ottersen, '86). 2) The distribution of Gluand Asp-labelled neurons in various areas of the cerebral cortex (Conti et al., '87a,b; Dori et al., '89) did not correspond to the pattern of labelling produced with metabolic markers, e.g., cytochrome oxidase histochemistry (Conti et al., '87b). 3) Gluand Asp-containing cells were located in layers that previous indirect methods, such as the autoradiographic localization of retrogradely transported D-L3Hl-Asp, have suggested to contain glutamergic or aspartergic neurons.
In addition, Glu-positive neurons were not localized in layer I, which lacks pyramidal cells (Dori et al., '89). 4) Gluor Asp-immunoreactive axon terminals in the rat visual cortex moo 0 a a 0

(Dori et al., '89), cat neocortex (DeFelipe et al., '88; Conti et al., '89) and rat spinal cord (Weinberg et al., '87; De Biasi and Rustioni, '88) appeared to engage only in asymmetrical synapses, which are associated with the release of an excitatory neurotransmitter.

Previous investigations of the neurotransmitters used by cortical efferent pathways often employed the autoradiographic localization of retrogradely transported, radiolabelled transmitter-related compounds.

The most widely used compound has been C3H1-D-Asp, as this can act as a false transmitter being selectively taken up by synaptic terminals that release Glu and/or Asp, without being readily metabolized after uptake (see Streit, '84).
Therefore, this compound has the advantage of being a neuronal tracer and a selective neurotransmitter marker.

However, the use of this technique results in labelling of only a limited number of projection neurons depending on their high affinity uptake system and, thus, may produce "false positive" or "false negative" results (see Cuenod et al., '83).
In addition, this method does not allow one to distinguish between glutamatergic and aspartergic neurons, as they share the same high affinity uptake system.

The advantage of WGA-HRP as a neuronal tracer is that it is nonselectively taken up by terminals and transported retrogradely to the somata of projection neurons irrespective of their biochemical properties.
The combination of WGA-HRP histochemistry with Glu-/Asp-immunohistochemistry used here allows the simultaneous visualization of the two distinct types of labelling within the same cell.

The results of the control experiments performed in this study suggest that the immunohistochemical procedure does not cause the masking or loss of the WGA-HRP reaction product, and also that the immunohistochemical reaction product is unaffected by the preceding WGA-HRP histochemical procedure.

The data presented here demonstrate that both Gluand Asp-immunoreactive neurons in the rat visual cortex give rise to afFerents to the dLGN, SC, pontine nuclei, and contralateral visual cortex, thus confirming and extending results from earlier indirect studies that proposed a neurotransmitter role for these two amino acids in the four pathways examined.
These results also suggest that the roles of Glu and Asp as transmitters are not identical or interchangeable.
Aspartate differs from Glu in that it is additionally present in a few nonpyramidal cells and that it is occasionally found in layer I.

Within each pathway the proportions of the two amino acids differ (Fig. 6), and the consistency of the results from the individual animals (see Tables 2, 3) suggest that these proportions are not the consequence of metabolic variations.

The sizes of the two types of cell also vary in that Asp-immunoreactive neurons projecting to the dLGN and pontine nuclei tend to be smaller than the corresponding Glu-immunoreactive cells, whereas those projecting to the SC are larger.
The different neuronal sizes could reflect differing axonal projections, and thus subtly different functions within the target site.
This suggests that the two transmitters may indicate two subclasses of projection neurons that might be distinguishable on morphological criteria if examined in sufficient detail.
cortical projecting to the dorsal lateral geniculate nucleus

The present results demonstrate that 60% of neurons in the rat visual cortex that project to the dLGN were Glu-immunoreactive, while 61% were Asp-immunoreactive, suggesting that Glu and Asp are the major neurotransmitters in the corticogeniculate pathway.
The similarity of percentages of Gluand Asp-labelled corticothalamic neurons raised the question of whether these two amino acids are colocalized in the same projection neurons.
This was not examined directly in the present study, but the issue of coexistence has been investigated by Giuffrida and Rustioni ('88).

These authors, using the same antisera as those used here, estimated that in the rat sensorimotor cortex 57-60% of cortieothalamic neurons were Glu-positive and 56-59% were labelled for Asp, percentages very similar to the ones presented here.

Furthermore, they demonstrated that in sections processed with both antisera, the majority of corticothalamic neurons were either Gluor Asp-immunoreactive, and only a minority (25%) was positive for both amino acids.
These data are also in agreement with other reports, suggesting that Glu and Asp are colocalized in a small percentage of neurons in the somatosensory cortex of the rat (Conti et al., '87a).
In addition, partial coexistence of the two amino acids has been reported to occur in other cortical projection systems examined (Giuffrida and Rustioni, '89a,b).
Indirect evidence from this study that the two amino acids are localized in largely separate populations comes from the measurement of neuronal areas.
These measurements have shown that the mean cross-sectional area for Asp-labelled neurons is 98.3 pm2 and that for Glu-labelled neurons is 117.9 pm2.
Our results demonstrating the involvement of these two amino acids in the corticothalamic projection system concur with experiments in which the visual cortex was ablated in rats.
These studies showed a decrease in the level of the endogenous L-Glu and in the high affinity uptake of Glu and Asp in the dLGN (Lund-Karlsen and Fonnum, '78; Fosse and Fonnum, '87).
Similar results have been obtained in the cat (Young et al., '81; Fosse et al., '84).
Direct evidence for the involvement of Glu in corticothalamic projections in the cat comes from a recent immunogold analysis of corticogeniculate terminals (Montero, '90).
The present findings also concur with studies in which injections of the tritiated D-forms of Glu and Asp were made in the rat dLGN.
Such injections resulted in retrograde labelling of cells in layer VI of the visual cortex (Baughman and Gilbert, '81).
The reports from these studies favour Glu as the major transmitter in these pathways.
However, Glu and Asp share the same high affinity uptake system and, therefore, a distinction between the two is not possible.
Cortical neurons projecting to the superior colliculus
Earlier studies have established the involvement of both Glu and Asp in the corticocollicular pathway.

A decrease in the level of the endogenous L-Glu and in the high affinity uptake of Glu and Asp has been measured in the SC and the dLGN after visual cortex ablations in rats (Lund-Karlsen and Fonnum, '78; Fosse and Fonnum, '87).

Although in one study retrograde labelling was not observed in the visual cortex after injecting D-[3H]-Asp in the SC (Baughman and Gilbert, '81), a more recent report (Matute and Streit, '85) found retrogradely labelled cells in layer V of the visual cortex of the rat, cat, and rabbit following injections of the tritiated D-forms of Glu and Asp in the SC.
This discrepancy may be due to the different fixatives used in these two studies (see Matute and Streit, '85).
The present estimation of the proportions of corticocollicular neurons that were d
LGN
sc
L GIu 3 f i Y o - A ~ ~ 49% c v c

also immunoreactive for Glu (46%) or Asp (66%) leads to the suggestion that Asp may be a more important neurotransmitter in this corticofugal system than Glu, and that Glu and Asp may be colocalized in a small proportion of these projection neurons.

With respect to their morphology it has been shown that corticocollicular neurons are long pyramids, i.e., their apical dendrites extend all the way to layer I and that they are predominantly found in the upper part of layer V (Schofield et al., '87).

The present study also demonstrates that corticocollicular neurons that contain Glu or Asp are large or medium-sized pyramidal cells, mainly located in the upper stratum of layer V of the visual cortex.

However, since the reaction product is confined to the perikarya and proximal dendrites, the morphological detail of the labelled neurons was not sufficient to confirm the observations of Schofield et al. ('871, which were based on a study of retrogradely or intracellularly stained corticocollicular neurons in the visual cortex of the rat.
Cortical neurons projecting to the pontine nuclei

The role of Glu or Asp as neurotransmitters in the corticopontine pathway of the rat was first suggested following the demonstration of high affinity uptake of Glu and Asp by synaptic terminals of corticopontine fibers (Thangnipon et al., '80), and a Ca2+-dependent K+-evoked release of [3H]-D-Asp from these terminals (Thangnipon and Storm-Mathisen, '81).

Transection of the fibers in the crus cerebri resulted in a severe reduction of high affinity uptake for radiolabelled Glu and Asp in the pontine nuclei (Thangnipon and Storm-Mathisen, '81; Thangnipon et al., '83).
Forty-two percent of corticopontine neurons counted here were Gluand 51% were Asp-immunoreactive.
This suggests that Asp and Glu may be the major excitatory amino acid transmitters in the corticopontine pathway, with Asp being a more common candidate.
However, the percentages of immunoreactive projection neurons suggest that these two are not the only transmitters used by corticopontine neurons.

Similar double labelling studies in other corticofugal systems have shown that a number of cortical projection neurons remains unlabelled in sections incubated in a mixture of antisera for both Asp and Glu (Giuffrida and Rustioni, '88, '89b).

This study concurs with the earlier retrograde tracing study of Wiesendanger and Wiesendanger ('82) that corticopontine neurons are located almost exclusively in the deeper portion of layer V in rat visual cortex, but disagrees with a later report that finds them in the upper middle part of layer V (Hallman et al., '88).

These authors also find that corticpontine neurons share many morphological features with corticocollicular neurons, whereas the present study concludes that each projection system has its own morphology and intralaminar distribution in addition to a characteristic transmitter proportion (Fig. 6).
Cortical neurons projecting to the contralateral visual cortex

Although the amino acid-containing neurons that give rise to callosal connections are distributed throughout layers 11-VI, analysis suggests that they are more concentrated in the supragranular layers.
In addition, quantitative evidence is provided in favour of Asp as a major transmitter in this projection system.
These results conflict somewhat with estimates from similar studies in the sensorimotor cortex of rats (Giuffrida and Rustioni, '89a).

These authors reported that the percentages of association and callosal neurons in the primary motor and the somatosensory cortex that are immunoreactive for Glu are similar to those labelled for Asp.
The discrepancies in the relative proportions of Gluand Asp-immunoreactive callosal neurons may be due to the different cortical areas examined.
The same authors also examined the possible coexistence of Glu and Asp in corticocortical projection neurons by incubating sections in a mixture of the two antisera.
Their findings suggested that callosal and association neurons are either glutamatergic or aspartergic, and only a small proportion of them are immunoreactive for both amino acids.

Other investigators have concluded that Glu and not Asp is the main transmitter of corticocortical neurons in the cat, as the former amino acid was immunohistochemically localized in 50-73% of these neurons (Conti et al., '88).

Although this may indeed be the case for the corticocortical system in the cat somatosensory cortex, it should be noted that in their study the proportions of putative aspartergic projection neurons in the corticocortical system were not investigated.

Considered together, the present results provide numerical evidence in favour of Asp as the neurotransmitter used most commonly by neurons in the visual cortex that project to the dLGN, SC, P, and contralateral visual cortex (Fig. 6).

Although evidence to support a transmitter role for Asp has been less compelling than for Glu, it has been generally considered as an excitatory neurotransmitter used by various cortical efferent systems (see Fagg and Foster, '83; Streit, '84; Hicks, '87, for reviews).
The present results also demonstrate that the proportions of Gluand Asp-immunoreactive neurons in each projection system examined vary among callosal and different corticofugal systems.

In addition to the neurochemical heterogeneity among cortical projection neurons, this study also demonstrates a morphological heterogeneity among Gluand Asp-labelled cells projecting to subcortical and cortical sites.
This morphological heterogeneity reflects differences in sizes of projection neurons, as well as in their cytological features.

For example, the Meynert cells in layer V, which are the largest cells in the visual cortex with a distinct cytology, are exclusively Asp-immunoreactive (Dori et al., '89) and project to the pontine nuclei, but not to the SC or the contralateral visual cortex.

The chemical and morphological heterogeneity between excitatory amino acid systems reported here is consistent with the functional heterogeneity of these systems at the level of receptors and physiological response (Ascher and Nowak, '87; MacDermott and Dale, '87).
At present, only limited information is available on other putative neurotransmitters used by cortical efferent pathways.
There is evidence that some cortical projection neurons may use the dipeptide N-acetyl-aspartyl-glutamate (NAAG) as a transmitter (Tieman et al., '87).
Other candidates include the sulfur-containing amino acids (SCAAs).
It has been shown that these substances exert strong excitatory effects on mammalian neurons (Curtis and Watkins, '63; Mewett et al., '83).
In addition, a K+-evoked, Ca2+dependent release of SCAAs has been demonstrated in the rat neocortex (Do et al., '86).

Most recently a study combining in situ hybridization with retrograde tracing using flurogold has demonstrated neurons in the rat cerebral cortex that express the gene for cholecystokinin and project extensively to the striatum and to some extent to the thalamus (Burgunder and Young, '90).

Acknowledgements.S: Rustioni for the gift of the antiglutamate and antiaspartate antisera.
The work was supported by the Medical Research Council.
